Several silica-alumina modified with Ag were examined as catalysts in the dehydration of 1,3-butanediol to 1,3-butadiene (BD). Among several catalysts tested, an amorphous silica-alumina (SAL-3) modified with Ag operated in H2 flow gave the highest improvement in catalytic activity and stability. The improvement of catalytic activity and stability of this Ag/SAL-3 was due to the generation of reversible acid sites. Several parameters, such as reaction temperature, contact time, Ag content, and carrier gas, influenced the catalytic activity of the Ag/SAL-3 catalyst. The highest BD yield of 82.5 % was attained at 225 °C, while the highest BD productivity of 1.33 g gcat -1 h-1 with a BD selectivity of 68.9 % was achieved at 250 °C. The role of the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was revealed by poisoning experiments of co-feeding 2,6- or 3,5-dimethylpyridine with 1,3-butanediol. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Amorphous silica-alumina Dehydration of 1,3-butanediol 1,3-Butadiene Deactivation control Poisoning experiment Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The incremental growth of rubber-related industries has significantly increased the demand for 1,3-butadiene (BD) [1,2]. The development of a sustainable and green strategy for BD production has to keep up with this growth since the major production of BD still relies upon the naphtha cracking of fossil fuels [3–5]. Supplying the demand for BD via catalytic transformation of biomass-derived chemicals can be viewed as a promising alternative since biomass utilization is a carbon-neutral process [5–13]. Due to this reason, the development of an efficient catalyst for BD production from biomass-derived chemicals is economically and environmentally imperative. The ethanol-to-butadiene (ETB) via the Lebedev process is a well-known and green strategy for BD production due to the origin of inexpensive bioethanol [13]. Nevertheless, efficient BD production via the ETB process requires a catalyst capable of catalyzing a series of different reactions, i.e., dehydrogenation, aldol condensation, hydrogenation, and dehydration. Alternatively, several reports have shown that BD can also be obtained via dehydration of biomass-derived 1,3-butanediol (1,3-BDO) [14,15], which could be obtained through the metabolic conversion of biomass [16,17]. In contrast to the ETB process, the BD production from 1,3-BDO proceeds via two consecutive dehydrations. Reasonably, catalytic design for an efficient BD formation via 1,3-BDO dehydration is more facile than that via the ETB process. Thus, the generation of BD via 1,3-BDO dehydration can be considered a viable alternative to the ETB process. Previously, we have reported efficient catalysts for the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to produce unsaturated alcohols (UOLs) and BD using solid acid [18] and rare-earth oxide (REO) catalysts ( Scheme 1) [15,19,20]. In general, the utilization of REO requires a higher reaction temperature than the solid acid catalysts. The mechanism of 1,3-BDO dehydration to BD over REO and solid acids catalyst is also different. The dehydration of 1,3-BDO over the REO catalyst proceeds via acid-base concerted mechanism, suggesting the importance of the acid and base sites of the catalyst. Meanwhile, the acid sites act as the sole active sites in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO over solid acid catalysts. Thus, the nature of the acid sites strongly influences the catalytic activity of the solid acids in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO. Several solid acids, such as aluminosilicate zeolite [14,21,22], Al-doped SBA-15 [23], and amorphous silica-alumina [18,24], have been employed as catalysts to dehydrate 1,3-BDO to BD. In those reported works, fine-tuning of acid properties strongly correlates to the catalytic activity in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO [14,21,23]. Several strategies have been proposed to finely tune the acid properties, such as adjusting the Si/Al ratio, doping the silica-alumina with Ce, and incorporating Al into SBA-15 [14,21–24]. In the case of acidic zeolite catalysts, high BD yield was influenced not only by the acid properties but also by the framework topologies [22]. Despite these efforts, the selectivity of BD rarely exceeds 70 %. Therefore, a highly efficient catalyst for BD production via 1,3-BDO dehydration is still highly desired. In addition to a low BD selectivity, catalyst deactivation has also been reported as another major issue in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO over solid acid catalysts, even in catalysts with optimum acid properties [22,24]. Pera-Titus et al. have reported that coke formation reduces the specific surface area of H-ZSM-5, reducing the activity in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO [21]. Padro et al. have studied the catalyst deactivation in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO, and they suggest that coke accumulation, which proceeds rapidly on the strong Brønsted acid sites, is the main reason for catalyst deactivation [24]. Similarly, Lee and Hong have also indicated that accumulated coke reduces the activity of zeolites [22]. They further reveal that the zeolite topology can alter the nature of coke accumulated on the zeolites during the dehydration of 1,3-BDO. Even though the utilization of diluted 1,3-BDO (10 wt% of 1,3-BDO in water) can reduce catalyst deactivation, the issue is unavoidable in the system which employs pure 1,3-BDO as feed reactant. Considering the importance of catalyst stability, the strategy to reduce catalyst deactivation is essential in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO since it can prolong the performance of the catalyst. In this regard, we have reported an efficient strategy of metal-hydrogen modification to improve the catalytic stability in the dehydration of alcohols [25–27]. In the strategy, metals play an essential role to dissociate H2 gas, while the spillover effect helps the hydrogen atom to be transferred onto catalyst [28]. The hydrogen atom can be transformed into proton, which desorbs the coke precursor, reducing coke accumulation. The hydrogen atom can also form hydride species, which can reduce the acidity of the catalyst and the consecutive side reaction by blocking the Lewis acid site. Baba et al. have utilized the redox properties of Ag in enhancing the stability of several acid catalysts in the presence of H2 gas [29,30]: the H2 gas is dissociated to form acidic protons which act as efficient and stable active sites in o-xylene isomerization and ethylbenzene transformation. Referring to these reports, the same strategy can be potentially applied to address the deactivation issue in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD over solid acid catalysts. In this report, a series of amorphous silica-alumina catalysts were employed for direct dehydration of 1,3-BDO to produce BD. In addition, several acidic zeolites with different Si/Al ratio and topologies were also tested for the reaction. A modification of catalysts with Ag and the operation in H2 flow were conducted to improve the stability of the catalysts. Some parameters, such as reaction temperature, contact time, Ag content, and carrier gas, influenced the catalytic activity of the silica-alumina catalyst and its product distribution. Performing the reaction at a moderate temperature with a prolonged contact time was conducted to minimize the side reaction, such as decomposition of 3-buten-1-ol (3B1OL) to propylene (PP) and dehydrogenation of 3-buten-2-ol (3B2OL) to 2-butenone (MVK) followed by hydrogenation to butanone (MEK); thus, ensuring a high BD selectivity. Poisoning experiments using basic probe molecules such as 2,6- and 3,5-dimethylpyridine (DMP) were performed to investigate the role of the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. This work is among the efforts in biomass valorization to produce BD via a green and sustainable process that could potentially reduce the global environmental stress caused by the conventional protocol of BD production. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Amorphous silica-alumina, SAL-3 and SAH-1, were supplied by Catalysis Society of Japan (Japan Reference Catalyst, JRC-SAL-3 with Si/Al = ca. 4.8, and JRC-SAH-1 with Si/Al = ca. 1.8, respectively) and another silica-alumina was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (catalyst support, Grade 135, Si/Al = 14 [28,31,32]). Acidic zeolites such as mordenite (H-MOR-20 with Si/Al =10.0), beta (H-BEA-25 with Si/Al = 11.7), and MFI type (H-MFI-90 with Si/Al = 45 and H-MFI-250 with Si/Al = 125) were supplied by Clariant Catalyst, Japan. A faujasite-type zeolite (H-Y, Si/Al = 3.15) was supplied by Catalysis and Chemicals Inc. Co. Ltd, Japan. The Ag-modified catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method using an aqueous solution containing a prescribed amount of AgNO3. The solution of 200 mm3 was dropped onto a support, i.e., silica-alumina or zeolite, and the water of the dropped solution was evaporated by illuminating the support with a 350-W electric light bulb at the support surface temperature of ca. 70 °C, this process was repeated until all the metal precursor solution had been added completely. The obtained sample was dried at 110 °C for 18 h and calcined at 300 °C for 3 h. The resulting catalyst is expressed as xAg/Z, where x and Z represent the Ag content in wt% and the name of the silica-alumina catalyst, respectively. 2.2 Catalytic test The catalytic test was performed in a continuous fixed-bed reactor under atmospheric pressure at a prescribed temperature. Before the catalytic test, the catalyst, typically 0.5 g, was pretreated at reaction temperature for one h in a flow of N2 or H2 gas at a flow rate of 1.8 dm3 h-1. After this treatment, 1,3-BDO (purity of 98 %), which was purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd., Japan, was fed into the reactor at a liquid feed rate of 1.6 g h-1 in a flow of N2 or H2 gas at a flow rate of 1.8 dm3 h-1. The reaction effluent was collected at 0 °C each hour. The liquid products were identified by gas chromatography (GC) equipped with a mass-spectrometer (GCMS-QP5050A, Shimadzu, Japan) and a 30-m capillary column (DB-WAX, JW Scientific, USA). They were quantitatively analyzed by a GC (GC-8A, Shimadzu) equipped with a flame ionization detector, a direct injection port, and a 30-m wide-bore capillary column of Inert Cap WAX-HT (inner diameter of 0.53 mm, GL-Science, Japan) using 1-hexanol as an internal standard. Gaseous components, such as BD and butenes (1- and 2-butene), collected in a gas-tight syringe were analyzed by an off-line GC-8A equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a 6-m packed column (VZ-7, GL-Science) using the N2 or air as an internal standard. The total mass recovered in the effluent liquid and gas was more than 97 % of the mass feed. The conversion of 1,3-BDO and the selectivity to each product were calculated according to the following equations: Conversion % = 1 − mol of recovered r eactant mol of the fed reactant × 100 Selectivity mol % = mol of carbon in the specific product × 10000 mol of carbon in the fed reactant × Conversion Meanwhile, the productivity of BD, P BD (g gcat -1 h-1), was calculated by the following equation: P BD = 54.09 × Conversion % × BD selectivity ( mol % ) 90.12 × W / F × 10000 where 54.09, 90.12, W, and F are the molecular weight of BD and 1,3-BDO, the catalyst weight (g), and the feed rate of 1,3-BDO (g h–1), respectively. The role of the Brønsted and Lewis acid was investigated by the poisoning experiments of co-feeding 2,6- or 3,5-DMP with 1,3-BDO. The procedure of poisoning experiments was similar to the above-mentioned reaction procedure, where 1,3-BDO as the reactant was mixed with either 2,6- or 3,5-DMP at 5 wt%. 2.3 Catalysts characterization The specific surface area (SA) of several catalyst samples was calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherm measured in a self-made volumetric gas adsorption apparatus at −196 °C using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method at p/p 0 range between 0.05 and 0.35. An N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of SAL-3 was measured at −196 °C using an automated gas adsorption apparatus (Autosorb1MP, Quantachrome, USA). The pore size distribution of SAL-3 at the nanometer scale was calculated from the desorption isotherm according to the Dollimore-Heal method [33]. The acid properties of the catalyst were evaluated by temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of adsorbed NH3 using BELCATII (Microtrac BEL, Japan) equipped with a TCD: the detailed procedure was described in the previous papers [20,34]. Prior to the adsorption of NH3, the sample was heated in a helium flow at 500 °C for one h. After the sample was cooled to 100 °C, the NH3 gas was introduced at 100 °C for 1 h. The NH3 desorption was monitored while the temperature was raised from 100° to 800°C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Because the TCD detector can detect gases such as water and oxygen desorbed from the catalyst, we also recorded a blank TPD profile of the sample preheated at 500 °C without NH3 adsorption. The blank TCD signal profile as a function of temperature was subtracted from the original TCD signal of desorbed NH3. A difference in the TCD signal between the NH3 and the blank TPD was converted to an NH3-TPD profile using the molar sensitivity of NH3. The number of acid sites was estimated from the integral of the NH3-TPD profiles up to the desorption temperature of 800 °C. The thermogravimetry analysis (TG) was performed using Thermoplus 8120E2 (Rigaku, Japan). A sample of 10 mg was heated in air at 110 °C for one h to remove the physisorbed water. Afterward, the weight change of the sample was monitored while the sample was heated from 110 to 900°C, with a heating rate of 5 °C min-1. To elucidate the nature of acid sites, Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was conducted using pyridine as a probe molecule and an infrared spectrophotometer (IRAﬃnity-1S, Shimazu Corp.). Prior to pyridine adsorption, a fresh catalyst was pressed until it became a thin disk and preheated in an IR cell at 300 °C under a reduced pressure (ca. 10−3 Pa) for 1 h. After the sample was evacuated at 30 °C for 1 h, a reference spectrum was recorded in the wavenumber range between 400 and 4000 cm−1. Afterward, the sample disk was exposed to pyridine vapor at 30 °C for 0.5 h. After sequential evacuation at 100, 200, 300, 400, 500, and 600 °C for 0.5 h, the spectra were recorded at 30 °C. Finally, FT-IR spectra were obtained by subtracting the reference spectrum previously acquired from each acquired spectrum. The reducibility of the catalyst was investigated by temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) using a self-made apparatus with TCD detector under the conditions: a sample of 30 mg was heated in a mixed gas of H2/N2 (=1/9) with the flow rate of 10 cm3 min-1 from a room temperature to 900 ºC with a heating rate of 5 ºC min-1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts screenings Preliminarily, the activity of the unmodified amorphous silica-alumina, namely SAL-3, Grade 135, and SAH-1, was investigated in N2 flow at 250 °C and a contact time, W/F, of 0.31 h. Table 1 shows the average conversion of 1,3-BDO over those catalysts, while the change in conversion with time on stream, TOS, is displayed in Fig. 1A. Notably, the SAL-3 catalyst (Table 1, entry 1) gave higher 1,3-BDO conversion than Grade 135 and SAH-1 (entries 2 and 3). Additionally, the SAL-3 catalyst had the highest BD selectivity with the lowest UOLs selectivity (Table 1 and Fig. S1). These findings suggest that the SAL-3 catalyzed the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to UOLs and its consecutive dehydration of UOLs to BD more efficiently than Grade 135 and SAH-3. It is worth noting that the selectivity of 3B1OL is higher than the selectivity of 2-buten-1-ol (2B1OL) and 3B2OL, regardless of the catalysts. This result is in agreement with the previous reports, which suggest that the dehydration rate of 3B1OL to BD was lower than the dehydration rate of 2B1OL and 3B2OL [18,22,35]. Nevertheless, despite having the highest catalytic performance, the SAL-3 had the most severe catalyst deactivation, as shown in Fig. 1A. Therefore, the improvement of catalyst stability is necessary to ensure that high catalytic activity can be maintained with TOS in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO. Table 2 summarizes the catalytic activity of SAL-3, Grade 135, and SAH-1 modified with 3 wt% of Ag in H2 flow. Ag modification and the operation in H2 flow led to a remarkable improvement of catalytic activity (entry 1) and stability (Fig. 1B) for the SAL-3 catalyst. Similarly, the activity and the stability of Grade 135 and SAH-1 also improved after the addition of Ag (entries 2 and 3); however, their catalytic performance was still inferior to 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst. It should also be noted that the selectivity to BD over 3Ag/SAL-3 was substantially higher than the one over 3Ag/Grade135 and 3Ag/SAH-1 catalysts. This increase in BD selectivity was accompanied by a decrease in UOLs selectivity, even for the selectivity to 3B1OL. This result suggests that the addition of Ag onto SAL-3 and the operation in H2 flow are beneficial for the formation of BD. Moreover, the addition of Ag did not substantially promote any side reactions since the increment of the total selectivity of side products was significantly smaller than the increment of BD selectivity. The outstanding improvement of the SAL-3 catalyst after the addition of Ag and the operation in H2 flow led us to explore the potential activity of other types of silica-alumina. Several acidic zeolites with different Si/Al ratios and topologies were employed as catalysts for the dehydration of 1,3-BDO (Table S1). Even though several unmodified zeolites, such as H-MOR-20, H-BEA-25, and H-MFI-90 (Table S1, entries 1–3), gave higher catalytic activity than the unmodified SAL-3 in N2 flow, a more severe catalyst deactivation was observed (Fig. S2). Other unmodified zeolites, such as H-MFI-250 and H-Y (entries 4–5), were inferior to the unmodified SAL-3, and those zeolites were also deactivated. The addition of Ag and operation in H2 flow were ineffective in improving the stability of the acidic zeolites (Table S2 and Figs. S2B and S3; Fig. S3 displays the details of the time course for each zeolite). Thus, the strategy to improve the catalytic stability using Ag + H2 are not appropriate for the tested zeolites. Fig. S4 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of unmodified SAL-3 and its pore size distribution. It is obvious that SAL-3 has mesopores at the peak top of 5 nm ranging between 2 and 8 nm. Table S3 compares the SA of zeolites and SAL-3 before and after modification with 3 wt% of Ag. The SA of SAL-3 and 3Ag-SAL-3 were 373 and 360 m2 g-1, respectively. The decline in SA of SAL-3 after Ag modification is only 3.5 %, which is correspondent with the percentage of Ag content. This result indicates that Ag deposits smoothly in the mesopore of SAL-3. In contrast to SAL-3, five zeolites have a large decline in SA after Ag modification (Table S3). The extent of the decline in SA was 7.2–26.1 %, indicating that the deposited Ag closes the pores of zeolites. This finding suggests that the strategy to improve the activity of zeolites by Ag modification needs a delicate protocol, which could not be achieved by a conventional impregnation method. Since 3Ag/SAL-3 gave the most remarkable performance in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD, further investigations were carried out using this catalyst. 3.2 Effect of reaction temperature Fig. 2A depicts the effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of 3Ag/SAL-3 at a W/F of 0.31 h, while Table S4 lists the product distribution. The average conversion of 1,3-BDO increased with the increase in reaction temperature, and nearly full conversion was achieved at a reaction temperature of 250 °C or higher (Fig. 2A and entries 3–5 in Table S4). The BD selectivity increased from 33.7 % to 68.9 % when the reaction temperature was increased from 200° to 250°C, and further increments in the reaction temperature decreased the BD selectivity. The increase in the reaction temperature decreased the selectivity to UOLs, especially to 2B1OL and 3B2OL (Table S4). This result indicates that 2B1OL and 3B2OL were readily converted into BD. On the other hand, significant decrement of selectivity to 3B1OL only occurred at 250 °C or higher, indicating that 3B1OL was less reactive than 2B1OL and 3B2OL. In addition, the decrease in 3B1OL selectivity was accompanied by the increase in PP selectivity. It has been reported that PP can be produced via 3B1OL decomposition, and the decomposition rate of 3B1OL increased with the increase in the reaction temperature [22]. Previously, the dehydration of UOLs, i.e., 3B1OL, 3B2OL, and 2B1OL, over silica-alumina clearly distinguished the reactivity of these UOLs [26]. 2B1OL and 3B2OL were readily dehydrated to BD with high selectivity (> 90 %) at 250 °C. On the other hand, the dehydration of 3B1OL to BD over silica-alumina did not proceed efficiently under the same reaction condition [26]. In this work, the different reactivity of UOLs was not affected by the presence of Ag and the operation in H2 flow, indicating that the BD production from 1,3-BDO over 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst still follow the general route of solid acids catalysis. Raising the reaction temperature also increased the rate of the side reactions, as the selectivity to MVK and MEK increased (Table S4). MVK can be generated via dehydrogenation of 3B2OL, and the consecutive hydrogenation of MVK produces MEK [35]. Alternatively, MVK can also be generated from 1,3-BDO [36]. Even though solid acid catalyst, such silica-alumina, catalyzes the dehydration more preferably than the dehydrogenation, the presence of Ag could slightly enhance the dehydrogenation reaction, as Ag has been known as catalyst in the dehydrogenation of alcohols [37,38]. Furthermore, the alcohol dehydrogenation proceeds more efficiently at high temperatures because dehydrogenation is endothermic [39,40]. These findings suggest that a moderate reaction temperature is preferable to minimize the side reactions; thus, ensuring efficient BD formation. 3.3 Effect of contact time, W/F Fig. 2B depicts the effect of W/F on the catalytic activity of 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst at 225 °C, while Table S5 summarizes the product distribution. Prolonging W/F increased the 1,3-BDO conversion and BD selectivity together with the decline in the selectivity to UOLs. Although the selectivity to PP also increased with the increase in W/F, the increment of PP selectivity was significantly smaller than that of BD selectivity. Efficient conversion of 3B2OL and 2B1OL to BD proceeded even at a short W/F: the selectivity to 3B2OL and 2B1OL was < 3 % (Table S5). In contrast, the selectivity to 3B1OL was substantially high at a short W/F, i.e., nearly 50 %, and a gradual decrement of 3B1OL selectivity was observed as the W/F was prolonged. The substantial increment of BD selectivity and slight increment of PP accompanied the gradual decrement of 3B1OL selectivity. It can be claimed that at a moderate reaction temperature of 225 °C, a competitive reaction between 3B1OL dehydration to BD and 3B1OL decomposition to PP occurred. Since the increment of BD selectivity is higher than PP selectivity, prolonging the W/F favored the formation of BD more than that of PP. In addition, at 225 °C, the increase of W/F did not significantly increase the side reaction, as the selectivity to MVK, MEK, and 1-butanol was less than 4 %. Under the optimum conditions at 225 °C and W/F of 0.78 h, a BD yield was 82.5 % with the BD productivity of 0.63 g gcat -1 h-1. At a constant W/F of 0.31 h, the product distribution via dehydration and the formation of other side products were sensitive to the change in reaction temperature (Table S4). On the other hand, prolonging the W/F at 225 °C substantially promoted the production of dehydration products with small increment of side products originated from the dehydrogenation (Table S5). It can be regarded that the dehydration products are sensitive to the change of temperature and the amount of 3 Ag/SAL-3 catalyst, while the dehydrogenation products are mainly affected by the reaction temperature. Therefore, prolonging the W/F at the moderate reaction temperature was more favorable for BD formation than raising the reaction temperature at a short W/F. Nevertheless, changing the W/F, i.e., amount of 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst, can alter the productivity of BD in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO. Fig. 3 and Table 3 show the BD productivity in the 1,3-BDO dehydration over 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst under different reaction conditions. Fig. 3A depicts that the BD productivity was high at a short W/F of 0.31 h; however, a higher reaction temperature of 250 °C is required for efficient BD formation. Since a higher reaction temperature facilitates a higher rate of side reactions, high BD productivity was achieved at the expense of BD selectivity. Figs. 2B and 3B indicate that prolonging W/F improves BD selectivity at a moderate temperature of 225 °C; nevertheless, increasing the amount of catalyst decreases BD productivity. The highest BD productivity at 250 °C and a W/F of 0.31 h was 1.33 g gcat -1 h-1 with the BD selectivity of 68.9 mol%. It is worth mentioning that the productivity and BD selectivity in the 1,3-BDO dehydration over 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst is higher than several reported catalysts such as amorphous silica-alumina [21,24,36], acidic zeolite [14,22–24], and WO3/SiO2 [35] catalysts. 3.4 Effect of Ag loading Fig. 4 reveals the effect of Ag content on the catalytic activity of xAg/SAL-3 catalysts at 250 °C and W/F of 0.31 h, while Table S6 lists the product distribution. The addition of Ag to SAL-3 improved the catalytic stability of the SAL-3 catalysts (Fig. S3), increasing the average 1,3-BDO conversion. The catalytic stability of the SAL-3 increased as the Ag content increased from 0 to 3 wt%, and further increment of Ag content to 5 wt% slightly decreased the catalytic stability. The change in the Ag content of the Ag/SAL-3 catalysts also influenced the product selectivity. The increment of Ag content from 0 to 3 wt% increased the BD selectivity while it decreased the selectivity to UOLs. It can be said that adding Ag onto SAL-3 up to 3 wt% favored the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to UOLs and its consecutive dehydration of UOLs to BD. However, a substantial decrease in BD selectivity was observed at an Ag content of 4 wt% or higher. Concurrently, the decrease in the BD selectivity was accompanied by the increase in the selectivity to UOLs, especially 3B1OL. These findings suggest that the increase in Ag content above 3 wt% leads to less efficient dehydration of UOLs to BD. The SA of the 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst was 360 m2 g–1, which is 96.5 % of SA of the original SAL-3, 373 m2 g–1, suggesting that the addition of 3 wt% of Ag still retains the SA of the SAL-3. However, 5Ag/SAL-3 catalyst had an SA of 323 m2 g–1, which is 86.6 % of the SA of the original SAL-3. These results suggest that excessive Ag content leads to the agglomeration of Ag particles which could fill the mesopore of the SAL-3 catalyst, leading to a decrease in the SA of SAL-3. The addition of Ag also alters the acid properties of the SAL-3 catalyst. The NH3-TPD measurement was performed to compare the acid site concentration of SAL-3, 3Ag/SAL-3, and 5Ag/SAL-3 catalysts. Fig. 5 depicts the NH3-TPD curves of the Ag/SAL-3 with different Ag contents, while the original TCD signals of the NH3-TPD are shown in Fig. S5. The unmodified SAL-3 catalyst contains the highest number of acid sites with NH3 uptake of 1.42 mmol gcat - 1. The Si/Al ratio of the SAL-3 is 4.8, corresponding to an Al content of 2.9 mmol gcat -1. Assuming that a surface aluminum cation provides an adsorption site of ammonia, it is indicated that half of Al is exposed on the SAL-3 surface. In Fig. 5, the addition Ag of 3 and 5 wt% onto SAL-3 decreased the NH3-uptake to 1.28 and 1.08 mmol gcat -1, respectively. The deconvolution of the NH3-TPD profiles (Fig. S6) further reveals a gradual decrement of strong acid sites of SAL-3 with the increase in Ag content: the strong acid sites of 3Ag/SAL-3 are calculated to be 0.42 mmol gcat –1, while 5Ag/SAL-3 are 0.31 mmol gcat –1. Considering that the SAL-3has strong acid sites of 0.63 mmol gcat –1, the deconvolution profiles suggest that the addition of Ag at 3 (Ag concentration: eq. 0.28 mmol gcat –1) and 5 wt% (eq. 0.46 mmol gcat –1) reduces the strong acid sites by 0.21 and 0.32 mmol gcat –1, respectively. Thus, it can be assumed that the presence of Ag did not contribute directly to the NH3 adsorption in He flow and that most of added Ag could exist in the form of Ag+ by exchanging an H+, which consecutively reduces the number strong acid sites. The changes in SA and acid properties of SAL-3 catalyst after Ag modification suggest that optimum Ag content is essential in ensuring the catalytic stability of SAL-3 without hampering the activity of the resulting Ag/SAL-3 catalyst in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD. Even though Ag is necessary to stabilize the catalytic activity of SAL-3, excessive Ag content could decrease the SA and acid concentration of SAL-3, decreasing the performance of the Ag/SAL-3 catalyst. In this work, SAL-3 catalyst modified with 3 wt% of Ag provides the best catalytic performance for 1,3-BDO to BD. 3.5 Effect of carrier gas on catalytic stability Fig. 6 shows the catalytic activity of 3Ag/SAL-3 in H2 and N2 flow together with SAL-3 in N2 flow. The unmodified SAL-3 deactivated rapidly within 5 h of TOS. The addition of Ag significantly improved catalytic stability as the 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst could maintain its high performance more efficiently than the unmodified SAL-3 catalyst. Notably, the 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst performed better and maintained its stability in H2 flow than in N2 flow. Previously, we have reported that adding Ag onto a catalyst and the operation in H2 flow can inhibit the coke formation during alcohol dehydration, thus, improving catalytic stability [25,27,41]. Fig. 7 shows TG profiles of the spent catalysts, in which the weight loss could be associated with the coke deposited on the catalysts. Intriguingly, the TG analysis of the spent catalysts indicates that the spent 3Ag/SAL-3 catalysts contain more carbonaceous species than the unmodified SAL-3 catalyst. Furthermore, the 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst operation in H2 flow led to a substantially more carbonaceous species than the operation in N2 flow. The amount of coke deposited on the spent catalyst aligned with their activity in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO: catalyst with higher activity contains a more significant amount of coke. Previously, Baba et al. have showed that the redox behavior of Ag in H2 flow can generate reversible acid sites that positively affect the catalytic activity [29,30]. Similarly, 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst could produce reversible acid sites when the catalytic reaction is operated in H2 flow. Furthermore, it has been reported that protons of the reversible acid sites generated from H2 with Ag modification provide a better catalytic activity than the original protons in the AgY zeolite [30]. This assumption is supported by the finding in Fig. 6, which indicates that the initial activity of the 3Ag/SAL-3 is higher than the unmodified SAL-3 catalyst. Notably, even in N2 flow, the 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst is more active and stable than the SAL-3 catalyst. Reversible acid sites could be generated from alcohols, such as methanol and butanol, instead of H2 molecules since alcohols can donate their hydrogen atom [29]. Table S7 shows effects of carrier gas and Ag modification. In N2 flow at 200 °C, the dehydrogenation of 3B2OL to MVK proceeded over 3Ag/SAL-3, confirming that H2 can be formed from alcohol in the presence of Ag. Although H2 was produced in the dehydrogenation over unmodified SAL-3 at 225 °C or higher, reversible acid sites cannot be generated due to the absence of Ag. This assumption is further supported by the fact that the unmodified SAL-3 was inefficient in dehydrating 1,3-BDO at a high temperature of 250 °C in H2 flow, suggesting that no reversible acid sites generated in the absence of Ag even in an abundant H2 condition. Therefore, the 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst could still form reversible acid sites even in N2 flow since the dehydration of 1,3-BDO produced several alcohols that can potentially donate their hydrogen. Nevertheless, the alcohols are less efficient compared to H2 gas in generating the reversible acid sites since the catalytic stability of 3Ag/SAL-3 in H2 flow is higher than in N2 flow. The assumption mentioned above also explains the difference in the carbonaceous deposits on the spent SAL-3 and 3Ag/SAL-3 catalysts (Fig. 7). The 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst possibly generated a higher concentration of acid sites when employed in H2 flow than the SAL-3 catalyst. Considering the acid sites are responsible for the coke formation, 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst contained more carbonaceous species than the SAL-3 catalyst. The TG analysis of the spent catalysts also indicates that the amount of coke on the 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst operated in H2 flow for 5 h is substantially more significant than SAL-3 and 3Ag/SAL-3 operated in N2 flow. This phenomenon can be explained by the rapid formation of reversible H+ when the 3Ag/SAL-3 is operated in H2 flow. This rapid formation of reversible acid sites leads to the rapid recovery of acid sites, thus, allowing a higher rate of coke formation. The formation rate of reversible acid sites generated from alcohol over the 3Ag/SAL-3 in N2 flow would be slower than in the H2 flow. Consequently, the coke formation in N2 flow proceeds at a slower rate. Regardless, since the operating conditions are significantly different, the increment of acid sites during 1,3-BDO dehydration in H2 gas cannot be detected by the NH3-TPD analysis in He flow. Even though the spent 3Ag/SAL-3 contained more carbonaceous species than the SAL-3 catalyst, the 3Ag/SAL-3 still provided better catalytic stability. The deconvolution of the NH3-TPD in Fig. S6B indicates that the unmodified SAL-3 contains a higher number of strong acid sites than the Ag-modified one. The number of strong acids decreases with the increase in Ag content. Strong acid sites are responsible for the formation of coke, which consecutively deactivate the catalyst. In the unmodified SAL-3, no reversible acid sites were generated due to the absence of Ag. As a result, once the acid sites in the unmodified SAL-3 were covered with coke, no more active site was available for the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to proceed, declining the catalytic performance. In contrast, the presence of Ag in the 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst allowed the generation of reversible acid sites. Therefore, even though the carbonaceous species blocked the acid sites in the SAL-3 matrix, the reversible acid sites acted as additional active sites for the dehydration of 1,3-BDO. 3.6 Poisoning experiment: role of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites Prior to the poisoning experiment, the presence of Brønsted and Lewis acid was verified by FT-IR of adsorbed pyridine. Fig. 8 shows the FT-IR spectra of the pyridine adsorbed on SAL-3 and 3Ag/SAL-3. The bands at 1460 and 1620 cm-1 indicate the pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid sites [42,43]. The band at 1490 cm-1 can be assigned to the pyridine adsorbed on the Lewis acid site, but it can also be ascribed to the pyridinium ion adsorbed on the Brønsted acid site [35]. Meanwhile, the bands at 1540 and 1640 cm-1 are associated with pyridinium ion adsorbed on the Brønsted acid site [42,43]. Increasing the evacuation temperature decreases the intensity of both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. Clearly, the bands ascribed to the Brønsted acid site remained up to the evacuation temperature of 300 °C, whereas the Lewis acid site still remained even after the evacuation at 600 °C. These findings suggest that SAL-3 contains strong Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. It is worth noting that the addition of 3 wt% Ag does not substantially alter the acidity of the SAL-3 catalyst. The overall FT-IR results (Fig. 8) are in agreement with the acid properties recorded with NH3-TPD (Fig. 5). Fig. 9 shows the poisoning experiment using 2,6- and 3,5-DMP, while Table S8 lists the product distribution. Previous reports have suggested that 2,6-DMP poisons Brønsted acid sites, while 3,5-DMP poisons both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [15,44–46]. Fig. 9A depicts the poisoning experiment in dehydrating 1,3-BDO over SAL-3 catalyst in N2 flow. The presence of 2,6-DMP decreases the activity of the SAL-3 catalyst, indicating that the hindrance to Brønsted acid sites decreases the activity of SAL-3. The catalytic activity of the SAL-3 catalyst in the presence of 3,5-DMP was slightly lower than the SAL-3 in the presence of 2,6-DMP. It can be assumed that the contribution of Lewis acid sites in SAL-3 for 1,3-BDO dehydration was lower than that of the Brønsted acid sites since the extent of poisoning by 2,6- and 3,5-MDP is almost the same. Therefore, the absence of Lewis acid sites gave an insignificant change to the catalytic activity of the SAL-3 catalyst. Fig. 9B illustrates the effect of 2,6- and 3,5-DMP on the catalytic activity of 3Ag/SAL-3 in N2 flow. The activity of 3Ag/SAL-3 declines in the presence of 2,6-DMP, which hinders access to Brønsted acid sites. The activity of 3Ag/SAL-3 further decreases when 3,5-DMP is introduced into the system. This finding suggests that the hindrance to Lewis acid sites further decreases the activity of 3Ag/SAL-3. However, the reversible acid sites generated by the 3Ag/SAL-3 are in the form of H+, which is a Brønsted acid. In addition, the contribution of Lewis acid in the SAL-3 matrix is poor, as indicated in Fig. 9A. Therefore, hindering access to Lewis acid should not significantly affect the catalytic performance of the 3Ag/SAL-3. It can be said that the role of Lewis acid in the 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst is not directly related to the dehydration of 1,3-BDO; instead, it is crucial during the formation of reversible acid sites. The following equation shows the simplified equation for the redox behavior of the Ag species in the presence of H2 gas [30]: ZO − + Ag + ⇌ ZOH + Ag 0 where ZO- represents the zeolite framework. According to the equation, Ag+, a Lewis acid, is essential in generating the reversible acid sites. As discussed in Section 3.4, it is reasonable that the added Ag forms Ag+ by exchanging an H+ with strong acidity. Furthermore, the presence of the reduction peaks in the H2-TPR profiles of 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst, which cannot be observed in the H2-TPR profiles of SAL-3 catalyst, strongly suggests that the Ag species in the 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst exist as a reducible form (Fig. S7). The Ag species might strongly interact with SAL-3, as the reduction peak of Ag species in the 3Ag/SAL-3 was located at substantially higher temperatures than the reduction peak of Ag of 3Ag/SiO2 sample. In addition, the 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst consisted of Ag species with different reducibility. The reduction peak located around 200 °C could be assigned to the reduction peak of small Ag2O cluster, while the reduction peak around 400 °C is ascribed to the reduction peak of stable and well-dispersed Ag+ ions [47]. It is worth noting that the Ag0 does not indicate monoatomic species, rather, it is some reduced Ag metals might form cluster of Ag3 + with unreduced ion [30]. This assumption is reasonable considering that the presence of easily reducible Ag2O cluster and hardly reducible Ag ions was confirmed by the H2-TPR (Fig. S7). The cluster of Ag3 + (Ag0) is essential in the formation of reversible acid sites. It is possible that the hydrogen gas chemisorbed on this cluster and undergoes heterolytic dissociation. Among several transition metals, Ag has been reported to have weak interaction to H2 molecule [48]. Even though this behavior suggests that the dissociation of H2 on Ag might have a higher barrier energy than the dissociation on transition metals, such as Pd, Pt, Ru, Cu, and Ni [48,49], the weak interaction between Ag and H2 means that the nature of H species on Ag is relatively reversible and it allows the spillover effect to proceed more easily. It has also been reported that the presence of support, i.e., Al2O3, allows the dissociation of H2 on Ag to proceeds more smoothly than that on bare metallic Ag due to the change in the electronic structure during the interaction between H2 and Ag [50]. Hu et al. have reported that heterolytic dissociation of H2 is more favorable than the homolytic dissociation on the fully oxidized TiO2-supported Ag [51]. Even though the nature of dissociation is highly affected by the nature of support and Ag, a similar behavior can still be considered in the case of Ag/SAL-3 catalyst. Following the heterolytic dissociation of H2, the proton acts as the additional active sites in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO, while the hydride species reduces the Lewis acid sites, consequently reducing the side reaction catalyzed by the Lewis acid sites. This assumption is further supported by the fact that the selectivity to a by-product of 4-methyl-1,3-dioxane over 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst operated in H2 gas (Table 2) was substantially lower than that over unmodified SAL-3 catalyst (Table 1). It has been previously reported that the catalyst that contains Lewis acid sites could generate a notable amount of 4-methyl-1,3-dioxane [18,36]. This finding further showcases the benefit of modifying SAL-3 sample with Ag and operating the 3Ag/SAL-3 in H2 flow. The presence of 3,5-DMP blocks the Lewis acid of Ag+, which consecutively inhibits the formation of reversible acid sites. Consequently, the catalytic activity of 3Ag/SAL-3 declines as fewer reversible acid sites are generated. A similar phenomenon could occur when the 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst is employed in H2 flow (Fig. 9C). 2,6-DMP blocks the Brønsted acid sites and directly hinders the dehydration of 1,3-BDO. Meanwhile, 3,5-DMP, which blocks the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, declines the performance of 3Ag/SAL-3 even further since it covers the active species for 1,3-BDO dehydration and the formation of reversible acid sites. 4 Conclusion An amorphous silica-alumina modified with Ag acted as an efficient catalyst for the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD in H2 flow. Several catalytic parameters affected the formation of BD: the operation at a moderate reaction temperature and a long W/F was preferable for BD formation due to a low rate of side reactions. The utilization of Ag and the operation in H2 flow possibly generated reversible acid sites, which are responsible for the high catalytic activity and stability of the 3Ag/SAL-3 catalyst. In N2 flow, the reversible acid sites are generated from alcohol which donates their hydrogen atom. The Lewis acid sites play an essential role in forming reversible acid sites. In contrast, Brønsted acid sites act majorly as the active site in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to UOLs and the consecutive dehydration of UOLs to BD. Under the optimum conditions at 225 °C and a W/F of 0.78 h, the highest BD yield of 82.5 % was attained at a full conversion of 1,3-BDO. The highest BD productivity of 1.33 g gcat -1 h-1 could be achieved at a short W/F and 250 °C with BD selectivity of 68.9 %. coredata.dc:description: Several silica-alumina modified with Ag were examined as catalysts in the dehydration of 1,3-butanediol to 1,3-butadiene (BD). Among several catalysts tested, an amorphous silica-alumina (SAL-3) modified with Ag operated in H2 flow gave the highest improvement in catalytic activity and stability. The improvement of catalytic activity and stability of this Ag/SAL-3 was due to the generation of reversible acid sites. Several parameters, such as reaction temperature, contact time, Ag content, and carrier gas, influenced the catalytic activity of the Ag/SAL-3 catalyst. The highest BD yield of 82.5 % was attained at 225 °C, while the highest BD productivity of 1.33 g gcat -1 h-1 with a BD selectivity of 68.9 % was achieved at 250 °C. The role of the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was revealed by poisoning experiments of co-feeding 2,6- or 3,5-dimethylpyridine with 1,3-butanediol.
